FLATS

NATIONAL SERVICE
(Reduction of period for graduates with specialist qualifications)


    3. Mr Lee Teck Him asked the Minister for Defence if he will consider reducing the period of national service from two years to six months for graduates who have specialist qualifications.

    The Minister for Defence (Mr Lim Kim San): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Singapore Armed Forces aims at building and sustaining an efficient and effective force of trained men in the Reserve. To be an effective Reserve Force, during the period of their full-time service the national servicemen have to receive a high standard of training. The Reserve

Column: 998

service can only maintain the standard that has been achieved, it cannot advance that standard.

    In terms of time, the necessary period for basic training requires between four and twelve months' training, dependent on the vocation of the national servicemen, even assuming that the national serviceman has had previous technical training. This must be followed by on-the-job experience and additional training to advanced levels in the respective vocations.

    Training of an officer takes up to two years depending on the vocation that he is being trained for, and his previous qualifications. Additionally, at least one year's experience as an officer is necessary before an officer can be considered for service in the Reserve Force.

    Another important factor to consider is that there is not a sufficient supply of skilled men available to enable rep1acements to be called up every six months. It is particularly important, therefore, that in the case of skilled personnel they serve at least two years of full-time service.

    Mr Lee Teck Him (Ulu Pandan)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am not satisfied with the reply given by the Minister. He said that it requires one year to train an officer, but graduates after passing out must have learnt a lot either in the field of science or art. They are scholars. So how can they be turned into soldiers? In my view, it is wrong. Graduates are specialists in their own fields and I feel they should contribute their specialities to the needs of our society instead of wasting their time in the army. Therefore, I think six months of training will suffice for them. I also feel that many people will oppose the continuation of two years' national service. Our country is not at war and there is no need to turn scholars into soldiers. Parents have spent a lot of money on the education of their children ---

    Mr Speaker: Order. Mr Lee, do you have a supplementary question?

Column: 999



    Mr Lee Teck Him(In Mandarin): Sir, in my view, it is very important that graduates, after passing out, should contribute their bit to society, particularly those overseas students who are reluctant to come back to Singapore because of the statutory requirement to undergo national service.

    Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker Sir, I do not think the Member has really listened to my reply. He may have his own opinion, but we have gone thoroughly into the question. I would like him to understand that this is a modern technological age, and in the army we require people with specialist training and of high mental calibre. Therefore, it is necessary that we should conscript into the army people with specialist training who have gone through the third stage of education in order to make the army a very efficient force.

    Mr Lee Teck Him(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the answer given by the Minister was not what I was asking for. What I asked was that two years training should be reduced to six months. He has not answered that point.

    Mr Lim Kim San: Sir, if the Member had listened very carefully to my reply, he would have heard why I said that it is not possible to train a man within six months.

    Mr Lee Teck Him(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, we can make use of Saturdays and Sundays to train these graduates. Of course, six months may not be sufficient, but we can find ways and means to give them additional training.

NATIONAL DEFENCE FUND
(Setting up of committee for public donations)


    4. Mr Lee Teck Him asked the Minister for Defence whether he has any intention of setting up a committee for the purpose of inviting the public to donate to the National Defence Fund.

Column: 1000



    Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, I stated late last year that the target set for the National Defence Fund is $10 million. At present, the fund stands at $8,343,897.84 as at 28th March, 1969.

    The National Defence Fund was officially set up on 29th January, 1968, as the result of spontaneous contributions towards national defence by some groups of citizens. Since then, donations from people from all walks of life, such as school children, taxi-drivers, hawkers, business concerns and Government departments, have been spontaneous, indicating a strong sense of loyalty and concern among the people.

    At this juncture, then, to set up a committee to invite donations from the public, in order to raise another $1.7 million more, would seem unnecessary, as most people are well aware of the existence of the National Defence Fund. I am sure, with some contributions from the large foreign and local firms in Singapore, the target would be easily reached.

    Contributions from the public must be voluntary, and must be willingly given by the people as the result of a sense of national pride and an awareness of the imminent importance of building up a defence capability.

    A committee inviting donations from the public, while advantageous in spurring up contributions, in money or in kind, might be construed as an instrument to coerce the public to contribute.

    Singapore is a society of very civic-minded people who contribute financially to many causes, and to those who can well afford it, I am sure they would willingly step forward to contribute to the National Defence Fund without any pressure.

    Mr Lee Teck Him(In Mandarin): Sir, the Minister said that since the target is about to be reached and the fund is going to be wound up, it is not necessary to set up a committee. But in my view, there ought to be a committee for public donations so that more money will be collected.

Column: 1001



    Mr Lim Kim San: Sir, I said that there is a limit of $10 million and there is no intention of continuing with the Fund.

ORDERLIES FOR GAZETTED
POLICE OFFICERS
(Particulars)


    5. Mr N. Govindasamy asked the Minister for Defence (a) what is the number of gazetted Police officers who are provided with orderlies: (b) how many of them are engaged (i) in field work which necessitates the use of orderlies; and (ii) in administrative work which does not necessitate the use of orderlies: (c) whether probationary Assistant Superintendents of Police, who are performing the duties of Inspectors and while carrying out routine investigations accompanied by Inspectors, are also provided with orderlies: (d) whether gazetted officers, who are serving in the Reserve Units and who have the use of Riot Squad vans for carrying out field work are also provided with orderlies: (e) what is the average salary of those orderlies and what form of training they have to undergo; (f) how do these orderlies spend their working hours when they are not driving their officers on duty, and whether there are definite instructions to ensure that those orderlies are kept fully occupied during their working hours; and (g) whether he will consider setting up a common pool of drivers/orderlies for the use of officers who are engaged in field work instead of providing drivers/orderlies to every gazetted officer irrespective of the nature of work he is engaged in.

    Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, the authorised strength of gazetted Police officers is 205 but the actual strength is 192. At present, 164 gazetted Police officers are supplied with personal orderlies.

    At present, 134 gazetted Police officers are engaged in field work and 29 gazetted Police officers are engaged in administrative work. However, administrative officers are also required to perform

Column: 1002

various types of outdoor duties depending upon the circumstances prevailing at the time.

    Probationary Assistant Superintendents of Police are provided with personal orderlies as a general rule except whilst they are under training at the Police Training School. Normally, Probationary Assistant Superintendents performing the duties of inspectors are not accompanied by inspectors.

    As regards the question of whether gazetted officers who are serving in the Reserve Units and who have the use of Riot Squad vans for carrying out field work are also provided with orderlies, the answer is "Yes".

    The average salary of these orderlies is $228.63 per month. Their training syllabus is similar in all respects to that of the regular police constables.

    Apart from driving their officers, the duties of officers' personal orderlies drivers include care and maintenance of officers' uniform and equipment, accompanying officers on rounds or other police duties, acting as messengers, drivers, personal assistants or witnesses when accompanying officers at all times and such other duties as the officers may direct.

    I am now holding discussions with the Police Adviser with a view to stopping this practice of supplying all gazetted Police officers with orderlies.

TRAFFIC ACCIDENTS
(Removal of deceased victims)


    6. Mr N. Govindasamy asked the Minister for Defence whether it is necessary for the Police to have the body of a traffic accident victim at the spot of his death for a considerable length of time before removal and thus induce a traffic jam.

    Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, the victim of a fatal traffic accident is removed as soon as the preliminary investigations at the scene of the accident are completed.

Column: 1003



    Mr N. Govindasamy (Telok Blangah): Mr Speaker, Sir, of late there have been cases of preliminary investigations going on for about two hours or more. Can something be done to speed up preliminary investigations on the road?

    Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, we will make every effort to shorten the period of inquiry. At the moment, we are compiling records of cases in which the police took a long time over the inquiry or the police hearse took a long time to come to the scene of the accident.

MAJLIS UGAMA ISLAM
(Particulars of collections and distribution of Fitrah)


    7. Inche Rahmat Bin Kenap asked the Minister for Social Affairs if he will ascertain from the Majlis Ugama Islam (a) how much Fitrah was collected in the last year of the Muslim calendar; (b) how much was distributed before Hari Raya Puasa and to how many persons: and (c) how much is the undistributed portion and what it is proposed to do with it.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Affairs (Mr Chan Chee Seng) (for the Minister for Social Affairs): Mr Speaker, Sir, the amount of fitrah collected in the last year of the Muslim calendar is $392,922.

    The amount distributed before Hari Raya Puasa was $32,482 and it was distributed to 19,759 persons, including fakirs, miskins and converts. After Han Raya Puasa, a further sum of $55,433 was distributed to the same fakirs, miskins and converts, as well as to those who were registered subsequent to the first distribution. In addition, a sum of $49,589 was distributed to the amils. The total sum distributed before and after Han Raya Puasa was $137,504.

    The amount left undistributed is $255,418. The Fitrah Committee of the Majlis Ugama Islam is working out a scheme to utilise this sum of money for the benefit of the Muslim community in the Republic.

REGISTRY OF CO-OPERATIVE
SOCIETIES
(Assistance to co-operative movement)


    9. Mr N. Govindasamy asked the Minister for Social Affairs (a) if he will state the nature and extent of assistance

Column: 1005

given by the Co-operative Development Division to the co-operative movement in Singapore: (b) whether he is aware that the Co-operative Societies Ordinance which was last amended in 1955, is outdated and if he will consider setting up a committee comprising officials from the Co-operative Development Division, the co-operative movement and the trade union movement to review the Ordinance: and (c) whether he is aware that many co-operative societies in Singapore are still contributing two per cent of their profits towards the upkeep of the Co-operative College in Malaysia and if he is satisfied that such contribution is of some positive benefit to the Singapore co-operative movement.

    Mr Chan Chee Seng (for the Minister for Social Affairs): Mr Speaker, Sir, there is no Co-operative Development Division in the Ministry but there is a Registry of Co-operative Societies which was transferred from the Ministry of National Development to the Ministry of Social Affairs on 16th April, 1968.

    Besides advising persons who desire to form co-operative societies on procedures of registration, the Registry provides informal instruction on the up keep of accounts and records to officials of co-operative societies, particularly the poorer rural co- operatives. It also acts as auditors to certain co-operatives which do not engage the services of professional accountants. In 1968, 34 co-operative societies made use of the services of the Registry as auditors for their accounts. The Registry also holds inquiries into co-operatives which are found or reported to be mismanaged with a view to deregistration. In 1968, seven such societies were deregistered.

    Although no representation has so far been made to the Ministry in regard to an amendment of the Co-operative Societies Ordinance, the Ministry will consider making amendments, if necessary, to the Ordinance in order to meet the practical difficulties which co-operative societies have experienced with the existing Ordinance.

Column: 1006



    Under the Co-operative Societies (Modification) (Amendment) Order, 1954, the contribution of two per cent from the net profits of the co-operative sccieties to the Co-operative College in Malaysia is not obligatory. As far as my Ministry is aware, only a few cooperative societies are contributing to the College. Since the separation of Singapore from Malaysia in 1965, only four co-operative societies have been contributing to the Co-operative College in Malaysia. Sixteen co-operative societies have made provision for this purpose but have not remitted such monies to the College partly on their own accord pending consideration of finding alternative places for them to undertake the training course. In return for such contributions to the College, officials of the contributing co-operative societies could participate in the short-term courses of formal instruction in cooperative subjects conducted by the College.

JURONG TOWN
(Building of fire station)


    10. Mr Ho Kah Leong asked the Minister for Social Affairs whether a fire station will be built in Jurong Town and when.

    Mr Chan Chee Seng (for the Minister for Social Affairs): Mr Speaker, Sir, although provision was first made in the 1966 Development Estimates for a fire station in Jurong Town, this provision was deleted in the 1969-70 Development Estimates on the ground of proximity of the Bukit Timah and Alexandra Fire Stations to Jurong Town.

    If it is found that these two fire stations are inadequate to meet the needs of Jurong Town, consideration will be given for the reinstatement of this provision in the Development Estimates of the next fiscal year.

HOUSING AND DEVELOPMENT
BOARD FLATS
(Particulars of eviction of tenants)


    11. Inche Abdul Aziz Karim asked the Minister for Law and National

Column: 1007

Development if he will ascertain from the Housing and Development Board (a) how many tenants of (i) one-room flats, (ii) two-room fiats, and (iii) three-room flats, respectively, were served with eviction notices in each of the years 1966 to 1968 for non-payment of rent: and how many of them were eventually evicted for not settling their arrears of rent: and (b) how many of the tenants evicted were known reci pients of public assistance.

    The Minister for Law and National Development (Mr E. W. Barker): Mr Speaker, Sir, the numbers of tenants of the Housing and Development Board fiats who were served with notices to quit for non-payment of rent for the years 1966 to 1968, the numbers of tenants who were eventually evicted and the number evicted who received public assistance are respectively as follows:

    (i) one-room flats: In 1966, 353 notices to quit were issued, the number evicted of which was six. There were six public assistance cases. In 1967, 763 notices to quit were issued, of which 10 were evicted and eight were public assistance cases. In 1968, 860 notices to quit were issued, of which nine were evicted and four received public assistance.

MISREPRESENTATION ACT, 1967,
AND CIVIL EVIDENCE ACT, 1968,
OF UNITED KINGDOM
(Introduction of similar legislation in Singapore)


    The following Question stood in the name of Mr P. Selvadurai ---

    12. To ask the Minister for Law and National Development if he will consider introducing legislation similar to the Misrepresentation Act, 1967, and the Civil Evidence Act, 1968, of the United Kingdom.

    Mr Speaker: Mr Selvadurai.

    Mr J. F. Conceicao (Katong): Question No. 12.

    Mr Barker: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Bukit Panjang will no doubt be aware that the Misrepresentation Act, 1967, in the United Kingdom was based on the English Law Reform Committee's Report, and introduced reforms to the law of contracts as well as to the law of torts. The scope of this Act, which has effected some improvements in the law, is far-reaching, not only altering the substantive law but conferring very wide discretionary powers on the courts. The Member will also be aware that the amendments to the law have been the subject of considerable comment and criticism in the United Kingdom. In the circumstances, it is desirable that a careful study of the Act and its effects as shown by the experience of the courts in England should be made before similar legislation is introduced in Singapore.

    Sir, certain of the provisions of the Civil Evidence Act, 1968, of the United Kingdom are already a part of our law of evidence. The Act, which was passed in the United Kingdom late last year as a result of the recommendations of the Law Reform Committee, alters the laws of evidence in relation to civil proceedings and in particular brings about certain changes in respect of privilege against self incrimination. The Member for Bukit Panjang can rest assured that the Attorney-General's

Column: 1009

Chambers is carefully considering the changes that have been brought about by this recent Act and the suitability of adopting similar amendments to the law of evidence in Singapore.

LAW REFORM (ENFORCEMENT OF CONTRACTS) ACT, 1954,
OF UNITED KINGDOM
(Introduction of similar legislation in Singapore)


    The following Question stood in the name of Mr P. Selvadurai ---

    13. To ask the Minister for Law and National Development if he will consider introducing legislation similar to the Law Reform (Enforcement of Contracts) Act, 1954, of the United Kingdom which amended section 4 of the Statute of Frauds 1677.

    Mr Speaker: Mr Selvadurai.

    Mr Conceicao: Question No. 13.

    Mr Barker: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Law Revision Commissioners responsible for the present Revised Edition of the Laws of the State of Singapore must have fully considered the amendment to section 4 of the Statute of Frauds 1677 brought about by the United Kingdom Law Reform (Enforcement of Contracts) Act, 1954, and for good reason thought fit to retain the law prior to the Amendment Act of 1954 in so far as Singapore is concerned when our own Civil Law Ordinance (Chapter 24) was reenacted. However, as there is considerable disagreement in regard to the scope and extent of section 5 of the Civil Law Ordinance, perhaps a case exists for our law to be amended on the lines of the United Kingdom Act of 1954.

    In so far as the Law Reform (Enforcement of Contracts) Act, 1954, affects the Sale of Goods Act of 1893, the matter has been set beyond doubt as we have seen fit not to extend the effect of that amendment here. Section 5A of our Civil Law Ordinance, added by Ordinance 23 of 1955, re-enacts section 4 of the Sale of Goods Act, 1893, in so far as it applies to Singapore, thus preserving the rule which necessitates a contract

Column: 1010

of sale of goods of $100 and upwards in value to be evidenced in writing before it can become enforceable. At this stage, Sir, I can only assure the Member for Bukit Panjang that consideration is being given to the desirability of incorporating the amendments brought about by the United Kingdom Act of 1954 by the Law Revision Committee which is presently working on a comprehensive revision of all the laws in Singapore.

    Mr Barker: Mr Speaker, sir, approximately 1,396 acres of land belonging to the Bukit Sembawang Rubber Company Limited, including those at Kuala Simpang in the Sembawang Constituency, are being acquired for the purpose of development by the Housing and Development Board as well as for resettlement and primary production purposes. REDEVELOPMENT PROJECTS

    Mr Barker: Mr Speaker, Sir, in keeping with Government's policy of encouraging investment and participation from the private sector in our urban renewal programme, the sales of urban renewal sites were held on two occasions. On the first sale, the total investment exceeded $90 million, of which about $70 million came from local entrepreneurs and the balance from abroad made up as follows: 

          Malaysia        $12  million

          Hong Kong       $ 4  million

    On the second sale, the tenders of which closed on the 14th of March this year for another 14 sites, 57 tenders were received from 38 tenderers. The Member will understand that it is not possible for me to give the amount and breakdown of foreign or local investment until the tenders have been fully processed and the offers accepted. The tenders, at the moment, are in the process of thorough investigation and careful study.

    Sir, the proposed developments for the various sites include hotels and shopping complexes, multi-storey car parks, office buildings, theatres, residential flats and a recreational Disneyland.

RADIO AND TV SINGAPURA
(Conversion into statutory corporation)


    The following Question stood in the name of Mr P. Selvadurai -

Column: 1012



    16. To ask the Minister for Culture if he will make a statement on the proposed conversion of Radio and TV Singapura into a statutory corporation; the need for such a conversion, and if such a conversion will result in changes in the cultural policy hitherto pursued by the Government in relation to Radio and TV programmes.

    Mr Speaker: Mr Selvadurai.

    Mr Conceicao: Question No. 16.

    The Acting Minister for Culture (Mr Wee Toon Boon): Mr Speaker, Sir, it has been thought for quite some time that the public of Singapore will be better served by a Radio and Television Service that is run by a statutory board or even by a commercial corporation. The pros and cons of this view have received considerable study and the advice of an overseas expert has also been obtained, but a final decision has yet to be made.

    The main advantage of a statutory hoard or of a commercial corporation, as opposed to a Government department of Radio and TV, is that such a structure leads to better operational efficiency and convenience. Radio and Television has just become financially independent in so far as recurrent ex penditure is concerned and it is now possible, therefore, to give serious consideration to a structural change.

    The Voluntary Sterilization Bill provides for a means of preventing the unwanted or harmful pregnancy by the sterilization of either the female or male partner of a union. There are far fewer ethical objections to these operations than those to the termination of pregnancies.

    But our present law in regard to sterilization is obscure and much open to criticism. There is no specific reference in the Penal Code to sterilization except reference to emasculation, which is an offence defined as a grevious hurt.

    At present, sterilization is probably not unlawful provided there is full and valid consent for the operation and that it was done for the benefit or well-being of the person. But this is by no means certain.

    Unless sterilization is performed for the purpose of treatment, it might however be considered an assault on the person if performed for any other reasons, such as for family limitation, social and economic pressures, high parity and
